How to Compute the Angle between Two Vectors in A Stable Way

Sulley
2024-05-20
数学 - 数值分析
数值分析, 数学, 浮点误差, 线性代数, 计算机, 随笔

Your trigonometric teahcher must have told you given two vectors v1,v2\mathbf{v}_1,\mathbf{v}_2v1​,v2​, their angle can be readily obtained by taking their dot product devided by their product of norms:

θ=arccos⁡(v1⋅v2∥v1∥⋅∥v2∥)\theta = \arccos\left(\frac{\mathbf{v}_1\cdot\mathbf{v}_2}{\Vert\mathbf{v}_1\Vert\cdot\Vert\mathbf{v}_2\Vert}\right) θ=arccos(∥v1​∥⋅∥v2​∥v1​⋅v2​​)

Well, it’s mathematically correct but there is some difference for computers: numerical stability. For a very small angle, in which case the two vectors are almost parallel, the result of v1⋅v2∥v1∥⋅∥v2∥\frac{\mathbf{v}_1\cdot\mathbf{v}_2}{\Vert\mathbf{v}_1\Vert\cdot\Vert\mathbf{v}_2\Vert}∥v1​∥⋅∥v2​∥v1​⋅v2​​ can be very close to 1, and the derivative of arccos⁡(⋅)\arccos(\cdot)arccos(⋅) at 111, approaches infinity. This means that even a small precision loss in v1⋅v2∥v1∥⋅∥v2∥\frac{\mathbf{v}_1\cdot\mathbf{v}_2}{\Vert\mathbf{v}_1\Vert\cdot\Vert\mathbf{v}_2\Vert}∥v1​∥⋅∥v2​∥v1​⋅v2​​ can result in huge precision loss after arccos⁡(⋅)\arccos(\cdot)arccos(⋅) is applied.

Suppose the mathematically authentic value of v1⋅v2∥v1∥⋅∥v2∥\frac{\mathbf{v}_1\cdot\mathbf{v}_2}{\Vert\mathbf{v}_1\Vert\cdot\Vert\mathbf{v}_2\Vert}∥v1​∥⋅∥v2​∥v1​⋅v2​​ is ℓ\ellℓ, and the floating-number represented in computer is ℓ+ε\ell+\varepsilonℓ+ε where ε\varepsilonε is small enough. Then, the relative error can be written as:

θ−θˉθ=arccos⁡(ℓ+ε)−arccos⁡(ℓ)arccos⁡(ℓ)≈1arccos⁡(ℓ)(−ε1−ℓ2+O(ε2))\frac{\theta-\bar{\theta}}{\theta}=\frac{\arccos(\ell+\varepsilon)-\arccos(\ell)}{\arccos(\ell)}\approx\frac{1}{\arccos(\ell)}\left(\frac{-\varepsilon}{\sqrt{1-\ell^2}}+O(\varepsilon^2)\right) θθ−θˉ​=arccos(ℓ)arccos(ℓ+ε)−arccos(ℓ)​≈arccos(ℓ)1​(1−ℓ2​−ε​+O(ε2))

When ℓ\ellℓ approaches 111, the relative error grows to infinity even if ε\varepsilonε is fixed. With that being said, the precision loss embedded in the input number is magnified by the function that transforms the number. We call this numerical instability extrinsic instability.

Catastrophic Cancellation

According to Wikipedia, catastrophic cancellation is when subtracting approximations to two close floating values may yield a bad approximation to the difference of the original numbers.

Image the two real numbers are x,yx, yx,y, and their rounded floating numbers are xˉ=x(1+δx)\bar{x}=x(1+\delta_x)xˉ=x(1+δx​) and yˉ=y(1+δy)\bar{y}=y(1+\delta_y)yˉ​=y(1+δy​), where δx\delta_xδx​ and δy\delta_yδy​ can be relatively small. Their relative error, however, can be arbitrarily large:

xˉ−yˉx−y=(x−y)+xδx−yδyx−y=(x−y)(1+xδx−yδyx−y)x−y=(1+xδx−yδyx−y)\begin{aligned} \frac{\bar{x}-\bar{y}}{x-y}&=\frac{(x-y)+x\delta_x-y\delta_y}{x-y}\\ &=\frac{(x-y)\left(1+\dfrac{x\delta_x-y\delta_y}{x-y}\right)}{x-y}\\ &=\left(1+\dfrac{x\delta_x-y\delta_y}{x-y}\right) \end{aligned} x−yxˉ−yˉ​​​=x−y(x−y)+xδx​−yδy​​=x−y(x−y)(1+x−yxδx​−yδy​​)​=(1+x−yxδx​−yδy​​)​

The relative error ∣xδx−yδyx−y∣\left\vert\dfrac{x\delta_x-y\delta_y}{x-y}\right\vert∣∣∣∣∣​x−yxδx​−yδy​​∣∣∣∣∣​ is fixed if δx=δy\delta_x=\delta_yδx​=δy​, but this is not generally possible in practice. If ∣δx∣≥10−n,∣δy∣≥10−n|\delta_x|\ge 10^{-n},|\delta_y|\ge 10^{-n}∣δx​∣≥10−n,∣δy​∣≥10−n, and ∣δx−δy∣≥10−n|\delta_x-\delta_y|\ge10^{-n}∣δx​−δy​∣≥10−n, and assume x>y>0,δx>0,δx−δy>0x>y>0,\delta_x>0,\delta_x-\delta_y>0x>y>0,δx​>0,δx​−δy​>0, we can estimate the relative error as follows:

∣xδx−yδyx−y∣=∣(x−y)δx+y(δx−δy)x−y∣=δx+yx−y(δx−δy)≥10−nxx−y\begin{aligned} \left\vert\dfrac{x\delta_x-y\delta_y}{x-y}\right\vert &= \left\vert\frac{(x-y)\delta_x+y(\delta_x-\delta_y)}{x-y}\right\vert\\ &=\delta_x+\frac{y}{x-y}(\delta_x-\delta_y)\\ &\ge 10^{-n}\frac{x}{x-y} \end{aligned} ∣∣∣∣∣​x−yxδx​−yδy​​∣∣∣∣∣​​=∣∣∣∣∣​x−y(x−y)δx​+y(δx​−δy​)​∣∣∣∣∣​=δx​+x−yy​(δx​−δy​)≥10−nx−yx​​

This shows that if xxx and yyy are close enough, the relative error can be large, much larger than 10−n10^{-n}10−n. But note that the catastrophic cancellation issue is only related to relative error, not absolute error. This means that even if the relative error is very large, the absolute error can be very small relative to the operand’s own magnitude. We care about the relative error because it’s highly related to the precision of the significand. For example, assume the actual number is 1.9999999×2−201.9999999\times 2^{-20}1.9999999×2−20 and the floating-point representation is 1.99994575‾×2−201.9999\underline{4575}\times 2^{-20}1.99994575​×2−20. The latter loses half precision of the significand, but the absolute error, scaled down by a factor of 2−202^{-20}2−20, is very small.

So what about other arithmetics like addition, multiplication and division? Let’s examine them.

For addition:

∣x(1+δx)+y(1+δy)−(x+y)x+y∣=∣xδx+yδyx+y∣≤∣xx+yδx∣+∣yx+yδy∣\begin{aligned} \left\vert \frac{x(1+\delta_x)+y(1+\delta_y)-(x+y)}{x+y} \right\vert &= \left\vert \frac{x\delta_x+y\delta_y}{x+y} \right\vert\\ &\le \left\vert \frac{x}{x+y}\delta_x \right\vert+\left\vert \frac{y}{x+y}\delta_y \right\vert \end{aligned} ∣∣∣∣∣​x+yx(1+δx​)+y(1+δy​)−(x+y)​∣∣∣∣∣​​=∣∣∣∣∣​x+yxδx​+yδy​​∣∣∣∣∣​≤∣∣∣∣∣​x+yx​δx​∣∣∣∣∣​+∣∣∣∣∣​x+yy​δy​∣∣∣∣∣​​

We can see that addition is bounded as long as xxx is not close to −y-y−y. Next we test the relative error of multiplication.

∣x(1+δx)y(1+δy)−xyxy∣=∣(1+δx)(1+δy)−1∣=∣δx+δy+δxδy∣\begin{aligned} \left\vert \frac{x(1+\delta_x)y(1+\delta_y)-xy}{xy} \right\vert &= \left\vert (1+\delta_x)(1+\delta_y)-1 \right\vert\\ &= \left\vert \delta_x+\delta_y+\delta_x\delta_y \right\vert \end{aligned} ∣∣∣∣∣​xyx(1+δx​)y(1+δy​)−xy​∣∣∣∣∣​​=∣(1+δx​)(1+δy​)−1∣=∣δx​+δy​+δx​δy​∣​

which is tightly bounded.

You can also check division is also bounded by the relative error introduced from each floating number operand.

As an example for subtraction, consider calculating the following value when xxx is small enough (x→0x\to 0x→0):

f(x)=1−cos⁡(x)x2f(x)=\frac{1-\cos(x)}{x^2} f(x)=x21−cos(x)​

By calculus knowledge we know that lim⁡x→0f(x)=1/2\lim_{x\to 0}f(x)=1/2limx→0​f(x)=1/2, but due to precision loss of cos⁡(x)\cos(x)cos(x) when x→0x\to 0x→0, the value of 1−cos⁡(x)1-\cos(x)1−cos(x) will be 0, and zero divided by a non-zero value is zero itself.

Matt Pharr’s post gives another great example illustrating this problem. Due to the 32-bit floating point representation, the multiplication of two large floating number will be rounded up at the base of −1×109-1\times 10^9−1×109. This tells us that the floating number naturally comes with precision loss, but when we do the calculation properly, the precision loss can be significantly mitigated. The general idea is try to maintain precision for each expression and not leave subtraction to the final step.

We call the numerical instability brought by floating number representation as intrinsic instability. This post discusses extrinsic instability for most of the time. For more details about intrinsic instability, or catastrophic cancellation, I recommend reading Bruce Dawson’s post about floating numbers.

Four Ways to Compute Angles Between Vectors

There are four popular ways to compute the angle between two vectors including the unstable trivial one introduced at the beginning.

Equation (4)(4)(4) is simply an equivalent representation of equation (3)(3)(3) as arctan⁡(y,x)=arctan⁡(ay,ax)\arctan(y, x)=\arctan(ay, ax)arctan(y,x)=arctan(ay,ax), where a=∥v1∥∥v2∥a=\Vert\mathbf{v}_1\Vert\Vert\mathbf{v}_2\Verta=∥v1​∥∥v2​∥ in this case.

To prove the correctness of equation (2)(2)(2), just note that ∥v1×v2∥=∥v1∥⋅∥v2∥∣sin⁡(θ)∣\Vert\mathbf{v}_1\times\mathbf{v}_2\Vert=\Vert\mathbf{v}_1\Vert\cdot\Vert\mathbf{v}_2\Vert|\sin(\theta)|∥v1​×v2​∥=∥v1​∥⋅∥v2​∥∣sin(θ)∣ and v1⋅v2=∥v1∥⋅∥v2∥cos⁡(θ)\mathbf{v}_1\cdot\mathbf{v}_2=\Vert\mathbf{v}_1\Vert\cdot\Vert\mathbf{v}_2\Vert\cos(\theta)v1​⋅v2​=∥v1​∥⋅∥v2​∥cos(θ).

To prove the correctness of equation (3)(3)(3) (and thus equation (4)(4)(4)), we can assume v1\mathbf{v}_1v1​ and v2\mathbf{v}_2v2​ are both normalized without loss of generality. Then ∥v1−v2∥=2(1−cos⁡(θ))\Vert\mathbf{v}_1-\mathbf{v}_2\Vert=\sqrt{2(1-\cos(\theta))}∥v1​−v2​∥=2(1−cos(θ))​ and ∥v1+v2∥=2(1+cos⁡(θ))\Vert\mathbf{v}_1+\mathbf{v}_2\Vert=\sqrt{2(1+\cos(\theta))}∥v1​+v2​∥=2(1+cos(θ))​. Their fraction is:

1−cos⁡(θ)1+cos⁡(θ)=2sin⁡2(θ/2)2cos⁡2(θ/2)=∣tan⁡(θ2)∣\sqrt{\frac{1-\cos(\theta)}{1+\cos(\theta)}}=\sqrt{\frac{2\sin^2(\theta/2)}{2\cos^2(\theta/2)}}=\left\vert\tan\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right)\right\vert 1+cos(θ)1−cos(θ)​​=2cos2(θ/2)2sin2(θ/2)​​=∣∣∣∣∣​tan(2θ​)∣∣∣∣∣​

Proof completes.

Mathematical Analysis

According to which type of instability is chosen, we can analyze and compare the relative error of each method. In the following sections, we use fl(⋅)\text{fl}(\cdot)fl(⋅) to denote the floating point representation of the exact input value.

Extrinsic Relative Error

In extrainsic relative error analysis, we assume the overall input has a fixed relative error: fl(x)=x(1+εx)\text{fl}(x)=x(1+\varepsilon_x)fl(x)=x(1+εx​) where −2−23≤εx≤2−23-2^{-23}\le \varepsilon_x\le 2^{-23}−2−23≤εx​≤2−23.

For the first method, the extrinsic relative error is:

      fl(arccos⁡(fl(x)))−arccos⁡(x)arccos⁡(x)=(1+εa)arccos⁡(x(1+εx))−arccos⁡(x)arccos⁡(x)=(1+εa)(arccos⁡(x)−xεx1−x2+O(εx2))−arccos⁡(x)arccos⁡(x)=εa−εx(1+εa)xarccos⁡(x)1−x2+(1+εa)O(εx2)arccos⁡(x)\begin{aligned} &~~~~~~\frac{\text{fl}\left(\arccos(\text{fl}(x))\right)-\arccos(x)}{\arccos(x)}\\ &=\frac{(1+\varepsilon_a)\arccos(x(1+\varepsilon_x))-\arccos(x)}{\arccos(x)}\\ &=\frac{(1+\varepsilon_a)\left(\arccos(x)-\dfrac{x\varepsilon_x}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}+O(\varepsilon_x^2)\right)-\arccos(x)}{\arccos(x)}\\ &=\varepsilon_a-\varepsilon_x(1+\varepsilon_a)\frac{x}{\arccos(x)\sqrt{1-x^2}}+(1+\varepsilon_a)\frac{O(\varepsilon_x^2)}{\arccos(x)} \end{aligned} ​      arccos(x)fl(arccos(fl(x)))−arccos(x)​=arccos(x)(1+εa​)arccos(x(1+εx​))−arccos(x)​=arccos(x)(1+εa​)(arccos(x)−1−x2​xεx​​+O(εx2​))−arccos(x)​=εa​−εx​(1+εa​)arccos(x)1−x2​x​+(1+εa​)arccos(x)O(εx2​)​​

When x→1x\to 1x→1, the second term would approach infinity. The extrinsic relative error of method one is unbounded.

Now let’s examine the second method. It’s extrinsic relative error is:

      fl(arctan⁡(fl(x)))−arctan⁡(x)arctan⁡(x)=(1+εa)arctan⁡(x(1+εx))−arctan⁡(x)arctan⁡(x)=(1+εa)(arctan⁡(x)+xεx1+x2+O(εx2))−arctan⁡(x)arctan⁡(x)=εa+εx(1+εa)xarctan⁡(x)(1+x2)+(1+εa)O(εx2)arctan⁡(x)\begin{aligned} &~~~~~~\frac{\text{fl}(\arctan(\text{fl}(x)))-\arctan(x)}{\arctan(x)}\\ &=\frac{(1+\varepsilon_a)\arctan(x(1+\varepsilon_x))-\arctan(x)}{\arctan(x)}\\ &=\frac{(1+\varepsilon_a)\left(\arctan(x)+\dfrac{x\varepsilon_x}{1+x^2}+O(\varepsilon_x^2)\right)-\arctan(x)}{\arctan(x)}\\ &=\varepsilon_a+\varepsilon_x(1+\varepsilon_a)\frac{x}{\arctan(x)(1+x^2)}+(1+\varepsilon_a)\frac{O(\varepsilon_x^2)}{\arctan(x)} \end{aligned} ​      arctan(x)fl(arctan(fl(x)))−arctan(x)​=arctan(x)(1+εa​)arctan(x(1+εx​))−arctan(x)​=arctan(x)(1+εa​)(arctan(x)+1+x2xεx​​+O(εx2​))−arctan(x)​=εa​+εx​(1+εa​)arctan(x)(1+x2)x​+(1+εa​)arctan(x)O(εx2​)​​

Note that x∼arctan⁡(x)x\sim\arctan(x)x∼arctan(x) when x→0x\to 0x→0, so the second term is bounded and thus the extrinsic relative error of the second/third/forth method is bounded.

Intrinsic Relative Error

Evaluating the instrinsic relative error is much more difficult. We use xˉ=x(1+δx)\bar{x}=x(1+\delta_x)xˉ=x(1+δx​) to represent the floating-point representation of any exact value xxx, with its relative error 2−24≤∣δx∣≤x−232^{-24}\le |\delta_x|\le x^{-23}2−24≤∣δx​∣≤x−23. The following notations are used in this section:

xˉ1=x1(1+δx1),  xˉ2=x2(1+δx2)yˉ1=y1(1+δy1),  yˉ2=y2(1+δy2)zˉ1=z1(1+δz1),  zˉ2=z2(1+δz2)v1=(x1,y1,z1)⊤,  v2=(x2,y2,z2)⊤vˉ1=(xˉ1,yˉ1,zˉ1)⊤,  vˉ2=(xˉ2,yˉ2,zˉ2)⊤\begin{aligned} \bar{x}_1=x_1(1+\delta_{x_1}),&~~\bar{x}_2=x_2(1+\delta_{x_2})\\ \bar{y}_1=y_1(1+\delta_{y_1}),&~~\bar{y}_2=y_2(1+\delta_{y_2})\\ \bar{z}_1=z_1(1+\delta_{z_1}),&~~\bar{z}_2=z_2(1+\delta_{z_2})\\ \mathbf{v}_1=(x_1,y_1,z_1)^\top,&~~\mathbf{v}_2=(x_2,y_2,z_2)^\top\\ \bar{\mathbf{v}}_1=(\bar{x}_1,\bar{y}_1,\bar{z}_1)^\top,&~~\bar{\mathbf{v}}_2=(\bar{x}_2,\bar{y}_2,\bar{z}_2)^\top \end{aligned} xˉ1​=x1​(1+δx1​​),yˉ​1​=y1​(1+δy1​​),zˉ1​=z1​(1+δz1​​),v1​=(x1​,y1​,z1​)⊤,vˉ1​=(xˉ1​,yˉ​1​,zˉ1​)⊤,​  xˉ2​=x2​(1+δx2​​)  yˉ​2​=y2​(1+δy2​​)  zˉ2​=z2​(1+δz2​​)  v2​=(x2​,y2​,z2​)⊤  vˉ2​=(xˉ2​,yˉ​2​,zˉ2​)⊤​

Note that:

∥v1∥∥vˉ1∥=x12+y12+z12x12(1+δx1)2+y12(1+δy1)2+z12(1+δz1)2∥v2∥∥vˉ2∥=x22+y22+z22x22(1+δx2)2+y22(1+δy2)2+z22(1+δz2)2\begin{aligned} \frac{\Vert\mathbf{v}_1\Vert}{\Vert\bar{\mathbf{v}}_1\Vert}&=\sqrt{\frac{x_1^2+y_1^2+z_1^2}{x_1^2(1+\delta_{x_1})^2+y_1^2(1+\delta_{y_1})^2+z_1^2(1+\delta_{z_1})^2}}\\ \frac{\Vert\mathbf{v}_2\Vert}{\Vert\bar{\mathbf{v}}_2\Vert}&=\sqrt{\frac{x_2^2+y_2^2+z_2^2}{x_2^2(1+\delta_{x_2})^2+y_2^2(1+\delta_{y_2})^2+z_2^2(1+\delta_{z_2})^2}} \end{aligned} ∥vˉ1​∥∥v1​∥​∥vˉ2​∥∥v2​∥​​=x12​(1+δx1​​)2+y12​(1+δy1​​)2+z12​(1+δz1​​)2x12​+y12​+z12​​​=x22​(1+δx2​​)2+y22​(1+δy2​​)2+z22​(1+δz2​​)2x22​+y22​+z22​​​​

Each ratio is bounded within [11+2−23,11−2−23]\left[\frac{1}{1+2^{-23}}, \frac{1}{1-2^{-23}}\right][1+2−231​,1−2−231​], so we can rewrite it as ∥vˉ1/2∥=(1+δ1/2)∥v1/2∥\Vert\bar{\mathbf{v}}_{1/2}\Vert=(1+\delta_{1/2})\Vert\mathbf{v}_{1/2}\Vert∥vˉ1/2​∥=(1+δ1/2​)∥v1/2​∥ where −2−23≤δ1/2≤2−23-2^{-23}\le \delta_{1/2}\le 2^{-23}−2−23≤δ1/2​≤2−23. The ratio of product to product can be expressed as:

∥v1∥⋅∥v2∥∥vˉ1∥⋅∥vˉ2∥=1(1+δ1)(1+δ2)\frac{\Vert\mathbf{v}_1\Vert\cdot\Vert\mathbf{v}_2\Vert}{\Vert\bar{\mathbf{v}}_1\Vert\cdot\Vert\bar{\mathbf{v}}_2\Vert}=\frac{1}{(1+\delta_1)(1+\delta_2)} ∥vˉ1​∥⋅∥vˉ2​∥∥v1​∥⋅∥v2​∥​=(1+δ1​)(1+δ2​)1​

For vˉ1⋅vˉ2\bar{\mathbf{v}}_1\cdot\bar{\mathbf{v}}_2vˉ1​⋅vˉ2​, we notice that:

vˉ1⋅vˉ2=x1x2(1+δx1)(1+δx2)+y1y2(1+δy1)(1+δy2)+z1z2(1+δz1)(1+δz2)=v1⋅v2+δ3where δ3=x1x2(δx1+δx2+δx1δx2)+y1y2(δy1+δy2+δy1δy2)+z1z2(δz1+δz2+δz1δz2)\begin{aligned} \bar{\mathbf{v}}_1\cdot\bar{\mathbf{v}}_2 &= x_1x_2(1+\delta_{x_1})(1+\delta_{x_2})+y_1y_2(1+\delta_{y_1})(1+\delta_{y_2})+z_1z_2(1+\delta_{z_1})(1+\delta_{z_2})\\ &= \mathbf{v}_1\cdot\mathbf{v}_2+\delta_3\\ \text{where}~\delta_3 &=x_1x_2(\delta_{x_1}+\delta_{x_2}+\delta_{x_1}\delta_{x_2})\\ &+y_1y_2(\delta_{y_1}+\delta_{y_2}+\delta_{y_1}\delta_{y_2})\\ &+z_1z_2(\delta_{z_1}+\delta_{z_2}+\delta_{z_1}\delta_{z_2}) \end{aligned} vˉ1​⋅vˉ2​where δ3​​=x1​x2​(1+δx1​​)(1+δx2​​)+y1​y2​(1+δy1​​)(1+δy2​​)+z1​z2​(1+δz1​​)(1+δz2​​)=v1​⋅v2​+δ3​=x1​x2​(δx1​​+δx2​​+δx1​​δx2​​)+y1​y2​(δy1​​+δy2​​+δy1​​δy2​​)+z1​z2​(δz1​​+δz2​​+δz1​​δz2​​)​

The intrinsic relative error of the first method is:

vˉ1⋅vˉ2∥vˉ1∥⋅∥vˉ2∥−v1⋅v2∥v1∥⋅∥v2∥v1⋅v2∥v1∥⋅∥v2∥=∥v1∥⋅∥v2∥∥vˉ1∥⋅∥vˉ2∥vˉ1⋅vˉ2−v1⋅v2v1⋅v2=cos⁡θˉcos⁡θ−1=vˉ1⋅vˉ1∥vˉ1∥∥vˉ2∥1cos⁡θ−1=1(1+δ1)(1+δ2)+Δcos⁡θ−1where Δ=δ3∥v1∥∥v2∥(1+δ1)(1+δ2)\begin{aligned} \frac{\frac{\bar{\mathbf{v}}_1\cdot\bar{\mathbf{v}}_2}{\Vert\bar{\mathbf{v}}_1\Vert\cdot\Vert\bar{\mathbf{v}}_2\Vert}-\frac{\mathbf{v}_1\cdot\mathbf{v}_2}{\Vert\mathbf{v}_1\Vert\cdot\Vert\mathbf{v}_2\Vert}}{\frac{\mathbf{v}_1\cdot\mathbf{v}_2}{\Vert\mathbf{v}_1\Vert\cdot\Vert\mathbf{v}_2\Vert}} &=\frac{\frac{\Vert\mathbf{v}_1\Vert\cdot\Vert\mathbf{v}_2\Vert}{\Vert\bar{\mathbf{v}}_1\Vert\cdot\Vert\bar{\mathbf{v}}_2\Vert}\bar{\mathbf{v}}_1\cdot\bar{\mathbf{v}}_2-\mathbf{v}_1\cdot\mathbf{v}_2}{\mathbf{v}_1\cdot\mathbf{v}_2}\\ &=\frac{\cos\bar{\theta}}{\cos\theta}-1\\ &=\frac{\bar{\mathbf{v}}_1\cdot\bar{\mathbf{v}}_1}{\Vert\bar{\mathbf{v}}_1\Vert\Vert\bar{\mathbf{v}}_2\Vert}\frac{1}{\cos\theta}-1\\ &=\frac{1}{(1+\delta_1)(1+\delta_2)}+\frac{\Delta}{\cos\theta}-1\\ \text{where}~\Delta &= \frac{\delta_3}{\Vert\mathbf{v}_1\Vert\Vert\mathbf{v}_2\Vert(1+\delta_1)(1+\delta_2)} \end{aligned} ∥v1​∥⋅∥v2​∥v1​⋅v2​​∥vˉ1​∥⋅∥vˉ2​∥vˉ1​⋅vˉ2​​−∥v1​∥⋅∥v2​∥v1​⋅v2​​​where Δ​=v1​⋅v2​∥vˉ1​∥⋅∥vˉ2​∥∥v1​∥⋅∥v2​∥​vˉ1​⋅vˉ2​−v1​⋅v2​​=cosθcosθˉ​−1=∥vˉ1​∥∥vˉ2​∥vˉ1​⋅vˉ1​​cosθ1​−1=(1+δ1​)(1+δ2​)1​+cosθΔ​−1=∥v1​∥∥v2​∥(1+δ1​)(1+δ2​)δ3​​​

It’s obvious that Δcos⁡θ\frac{\Delta}{\cos\theta}cosθΔ​ can approach infinity when cos⁡θ→0\cos\theta\to0cosθ→0. Therefore, the instrinsic relative error of the first method is unbounded when θ→±π/2\theta\to\pm\pi/2θ→±π/2.

Let’s go on to the second method:

fl(fl(∥vˉ1×vˉ2∥)fl(vˉ1⋅vˉ2))−∥v1×v2∥v1⋅v2∥v1×v2∥v1⋅v2=∥vˉ1×vˉ2∥vˉ1⋅vˉ2(1+δ1)(1+δ2)1+δ3−∥v1×v2∥v1⋅v2∥v1×v2∥v1⋅v2=v1⋅v2vˉ1⋅vˉ2∥vˉ1×vˉ2∥(1+δ1)(1+δ2)1+δ3−∥v1×v2∥∥v1×v2∥=∥v1∥∥v2∥cos⁡θ∥vˉ1∥∥vˉ2∥cos⁡θˉ∥vˉ1∥∥vˉ2∥sin⁡θˉ(1+δ1)(1+δ2)1+δ3−∥v1∥∥v2∥sin⁡θ∥v1∥∥v2∥sin⁡θ=(1+δ1)(1+δ2)1+δ3cos⁡θcos⁡θˉsin⁡θˉsin⁡θ−1=(1+δ1)(1+δ2)1+δ3tan⁡θˉtan⁡θ−1\begin{aligned} \frac{\text{fl}\left(\frac{\text{fl}(\Vert\bar{\mathbf{v}}_1\times\bar{\mathbf{v}}_2\Vert)}{\text{fl}(\bar{\mathbf{v}}_1\cdot\bar{\mathbf{v}}_2)}\right)-\frac{\Vert\mathbf{v}_1\times\mathbf{v}_2\Vert}{\mathbf{v}_1\cdot\mathbf{v}_2}}{\frac{\Vert\mathbf{v}_1\times\mathbf{v}_2\Vert}{\mathbf{v}_1\cdot\mathbf{v}_2}} &=\frac{\frac{\Vert\bar{\mathbf{v}}_1\times\bar{\mathbf{v}}_2\Vert}{\bar{\mathbf{v}}_1\cdot\bar{\mathbf{v}}_2}\frac{(1+\delta_1)(1+\delta_2)}{1+\delta_3}-\frac{\Vert\mathbf{v}_1\times\mathbf{v}_2\Vert}{\mathbf{v}_1\cdot\mathbf{v}_2}}{\frac{\Vert\mathbf{v}_1\times\mathbf{v}_2\Vert}{\mathbf{v}_1\cdot\mathbf{v}_2}}\\ &=\frac{\frac{\mathbf{v}_1\cdot\mathbf{v}_2}{\bar{\mathbf{v}}_1\cdot\bar{\mathbf{v}}_2}\Vert\bar{\mathbf{v}}_1\times\bar{\mathbf{v}}_2\Vert\frac{(1+\delta_1)(1+\delta_2)}{1+\delta_3}-\Vert\mathbf{v}_1\times\mathbf{v}_2\Vert}{\Vert\mathbf{v}_1\times\mathbf{v}_2\Vert}\\ &=\frac{\frac{\Vert\mathbf{v}_1\Vert\Vert\mathbf{v}_2\Vert\cos\theta}{\Vert\bar{\mathbf{v}}_1\Vert\Vert\bar{\mathbf{v}}_2\Vert\cos\bar{\theta}}\Vert\bar{\mathbf{v}}_1\Vert\Vert\bar{\mathbf{v}}_2\Vert\sin\bar{\theta}\frac{(1+\delta_1)(1+\delta_2)}{1+\delta_3}-\Vert\mathbf{v}_1\Vert\Vert\mathbf{v}_2\Vert\sin\theta}{\Vert\mathbf{v}_1\Vert\Vert\mathbf{v}_2\Vert\sin\theta}\\ &=\frac{\frac{(1+\delta_1)(1+\delta_2)}{1+\delta_3}\frac{\cos\theta}{\cos\bar{\theta}}\sin\bar{\theta}}{\sin\theta}-1\\ &=\frac{(1+\delta_1)(1+\delta_2)}{1+\delta_3}\frac{\tan\bar\theta}{\tan\theta}-1 \end{aligned} v1​⋅v2​∥v1​×v2​∥​fl(fl(vˉ1​⋅vˉ2​)fl(∥vˉ1​×vˉ2​∥)​)−v1​⋅v2​∥v1​×v2​∥​​​=v1​⋅v2​∥v1​×v2​∥​vˉ1​⋅vˉ2​∥vˉ1​×vˉ2​∥​1+δ3​(1+δ1​)(1+δ2​)​−v1​⋅v2​∥v1​×v2​∥​​=∥v1​×v2​∥vˉ1​⋅vˉ2​v1​⋅v2​​∥vˉ1​×vˉ2​∥1+δ3​(1+δ1​)(1+δ2​)​−∥v1​×v2​∥​=∥v1​∥∥v2​∥sinθ∥vˉ1​∥∥vˉ2​∥cosθˉ∥v1​∥∥v2​∥cosθ​∥vˉ1​∥∥vˉ2​∥sinθˉ1+δ3​(1+δ1​)(1+δ2​)​−∥v1​∥∥v2​∥sinθ​=sinθ1+δ3​(1+δ1​)(1+δ2​)​cosθˉcosθ​sinθˉ​−1=1+δ3​(1+δ1​)(1+δ2​)​tanθtanθˉ​−1​

The next step is to evaluate the ratio of two tangents, but its not as easy as expected. We then turn to evaluate their cosines and sines separately.

cos⁡θ=v1⋅v2∥v1∥∥v2∥sin⁡θ=1−cos⁡2θcos⁡θˉ=vˉ1⋅vˉ2∥vˉ1∥∥vˉ2∥=v1⋅v2+δ4∥v1∥∥v2∥(1+δ5)(1+δ6)=1(1+δ5)(1+δ6)cos⁡θ+Δsin⁡θˉ=1−cos⁡2θˉtan⁡θˉtan⁡θ=1−(1(1+δ5)(1+δ6)cos⁡θ+Δ)2(1(1+δ5)(1+δ6)cos⁡θ+Δ)2cos⁡2θ1−cos⁡2θ=1−(1(1+δ5)(1+δ6)cos⁡θ+Δ)1−cos⁡θ⋅1+(1(1+δ5)(1+δ6)cos⁡θ+Δ)1+cos⁡θ⋅cos⁡2θ(1(1+δ5)(1+δ6)cos⁡θ+Δ)2where Δ=δ4∥v1∥∥v2∥(1+δ5)(1+δ6)\begin{aligned} \cos\theta &= \frac{\mathbf{v}_1\cdot\mathbf{v}_2}{\Vert\mathbf{v}_1\Vert\Vert\mathbf{v}_2\Vert} \\ \sin\theta &= \sqrt{1-\cos^2\theta}\\ \cos\bar{\theta} &= \frac{\bar{\mathbf{v}}_1\cdot\bar{\mathbf{v}}_2}{\Vert\bar{\mathbf{v}}_1\Vert\Vert\bar{\mathbf{v}}_2\Vert} \\ &= \frac{\mathbf{v}_1\cdot\mathbf{v}_2+\delta_4}{\Vert\mathbf{v}_1\Vert\Vert\mathbf{v}_2\Vert(1+\delta_5)(1+\delta_6)}\\ &= \frac{1}{(1+\delta_5)(1+\delta_6)}\cos\theta+\Delta\\ \sin\bar{\theta}&=\sqrt{1-\cos^2\bar{\theta}}\\ \frac{\tan\bar{\theta}}{\tan\theta} &= \sqrt{\frac{1-\left(\frac{1}{(1+\delta_5)(1+\delta_6)}\cos\theta+\Delta\right)^2}{\left(\frac{1}{(1+\delta_5)(1+\delta_6)}\cos\theta+\Delta\right)^2}\frac{\cos^2\theta}{1-\cos^2\theta}}\\ &= \sqrt{\frac{1-\left(\frac{1}{(1+\delta_5)(1+\delta_6)}\cos\theta+\Delta\right)}{1-\cos\theta}}\\ &\cdot\sqrt{\frac{1+\left(\frac{1}{(1+\delta_5)(1+\delta_6)}\cos\theta+\Delta\right)}{1+\cos\theta}}\\ &\cdot\sqrt{\frac{\cos^2\theta}{\left(\frac{1}{(1+\delta_5)(1+\delta_6)}\cos\theta+\Delta\right)^2}}\\ \text{where}~\Delta &= \frac{\delta_4}{\Vert\mathbf{v}_1\Vert\Vert\mathbf{v}_2\Vert(1+\delta_5)(1+\delta_6)} \end{aligned} cosθsinθcosθˉsinθˉtanθtanθˉ​where Δ​=∥v1​∥∥v2​∥v1​⋅v2​​=1−cos2θ​=∥vˉ1​∥∥vˉ2​∥vˉ1​⋅vˉ2​​=∥v1​∥∥v2​∥(1+δ5​)(1+δ6​)v1​⋅v2​+δ4​​=(1+δ5​)(1+δ6​)1​cosθ+Δ=1−cos2θˉ​=((1+δ5​)(1+δ6​)1​cosθ+Δ)21−((1+δ5​)(1+δ6​)1​cosθ+Δ)2​1−cos2θcos2θ​​=1−cosθ1−((1+δ5​)(1+δ6​)1​cosθ+Δ)​​⋅1+cosθ1+((1+δ5​)(1+δ6​)1​cosθ+Δ)​​⋅((1+δ5​)(1+δ6​)1​cosθ+Δ)2cos2θ​​=∥v1​∥∥v2​∥(1+δ5​)(1+δ6​)δ4​​​

When θ→0\theta\to0θ→0, the ratio is unbounded. When θ→±π/2\theta\to\pm\pi/2θ→±π/2, the ratio can also be potentially super large. But it’s worth noting that as Δ\DeltaΔ is generally very small and (1+δ5)(1+δ5)(1+\delta_5)(1+\delta_5)(1+δ5​)(1+δ5​) is very close to 1, a significantly small value of θ\thetaθ is required to ensure the ratio unbounded. Due to the limited precision, the ratio is more likely to be bounded at a slightly large value.

Next let’s evaluate the third method. For brevity, we use the following notations:

u1=v1∥v1∥,u2=v2∥v2∥,uˉ1=vˉ1∥vˉ1∥,uˉ2=vˉ2∥vˉ2∥\mathbf{u}_1=\frac{\mathbf{v}_1}{\Vert\mathbf{v}_1\Vert}, \mathbf{u}_2=\frac{\mathbf{v}_2}{\Vert\mathbf{v}_2\Vert}, \bar{\mathbf{u}}_1=\frac{\bar{\mathbf{v}}_1}{\Vert\bar{\mathbf{v}}_1\Vert}, \bar{\mathbf{u}}_2=\frac{\bar{\mathbf{v}}_2}{\Vert\bar{\mathbf{v}}_2\Vert} u1​=∥v1​∥v1​​,u2​=∥v2​∥v2​​,uˉ1​=∥vˉ1​∥vˉ1​​,uˉ2​=∥vˉ2​∥vˉ2​​

Then we can calculate the relative error as follows:

fl(fl(∥uˉ1−uˉ2∥)fl(∥uˉ1+uˉ2)∥)−∥u1−u2∥∥u1+u2∥∥u1−u2∥∥u1+u2∥=∥uˉ1−uˉ2∥∥uˉ1+uˉ2∥(1+δ1)(1+δ2)1+δ3−∥u1−u2∥∥u1+u2∥∥u1−u2∥∥u1+u2∥=(1+δ1)(1+δ2)1+δ3∥u1+u2∥∥u1−u2∥∥uˉ1−uˉ2∥∥uˉ1+uˉ2∥−1=(1+δ1)(1+δ2)1+δ31+u1⋅u11−u1⋅u11−uˉ1⋅uˉ11+uˉ1⋅uˉ1−1=(1+δ1)(1+δ2)1+δ31+cos⁡θ1−cos⁡θ1−cos⁡θˉ1+cos⁡θˉ−1=(1+δ1)(1+δ2)1+δ31+cos⁡θ1−cos⁡θ1−(1(1+δ5)(1+δ6)cos⁡θ+Δ)1+(1(1+δ5)(1+δ6)cos⁡θ+Δ)−1\begin{aligned} \frac{\text{fl}\left(\frac{\text{fl}(\Vert\bar{\mathbf{u}}_1-\bar{\mathbf{u}}_2\Vert)}{\text{fl}(\Vert\bar{\mathbf{u}}_1+\bar{\mathbf{u}}_2)\Vert}\right)-\frac{\Vert\mathbf{u}_1-\mathbf{u}_2\Vert}{\Vert\mathbf{u}_1+\mathbf{u}_2\Vert}}{\frac{\Vert\mathbf{u}_1-\mathbf{u}_2\Vert}{\Vert\mathbf{u}_1+\mathbf{u}_2\Vert}} &=\frac{\frac{\Vert\bar{\mathbf{u}}_1-\bar{\mathbf{u}}_2\Vert}{\Vert\bar{\mathbf{u}}_1+\bar{\mathbf{u}}_2\Vert}\frac{(1+\delta_1)(1+\delta_2)}{1+\delta_3}-\frac{\Vert\mathbf{u}_1-\mathbf{u}_2\Vert}{\Vert\mathbf{u}_1+\mathbf{u}_2\Vert}}{\frac{\Vert\mathbf{u}_1-\mathbf{u}_2\Vert}{\Vert\mathbf{u}_1+\mathbf{u}_2\Vert}}\\ &=\frac{(1+\delta_1)(1+\delta_2)}{1+\delta_3}\frac{\Vert\mathbf{u}_1+\mathbf{u}_2\Vert}{\Vert\mathbf{u}_1-\mathbf{u}_2\Vert}\frac{\Vert\bar{\mathbf{u}}_1-\bar{\mathbf{u}}_2\Vert}{\Vert\bar{\mathbf{u}}_1+\bar{\mathbf{u}}_2\Vert}-1\\ &=\frac{(1+\delta_1)(1+\delta_2)}{1+\delta_3}\sqrt{\frac{1+\mathbf{u}_1\cdot\mathbf{u}_1}{1-\mathbf{u}_1\cdot\mathbf{u}_1}}\sqrt{\frac{1-\bar{\mathbf{u}}_1\cdot\bar{\mathbf{u}}_1}{1+\bar{\mathbf{u}}_1\cdot\bar{\mathbf{u}}_1}}-1\\ &=\frac{(1+\delta_1)(1+\delta_2)}{1+\delta_3}\sqrt{\frac{1+\cos\theta}{1-\cos\theta}}\sqrt{\frac{1-\cos\bar{\theta}}{1+\cos\bar{\theta}}}-1\\ &=\frac{(1+\delta_1)(1+\delta_2)}{1+\delta_3}\sqrt{\frac{1+\cos\theta}{1-\cos\theta}}\sqrt{\frac{1-\left(\frac{1}{(1+\delta_5)(1+\delta_6)}\cos\theta+\Delta\right)}{1+\left(\frac{1}{(1+\delta_5)(1+\delta_6)}\cos\theta+\Delta\right)}}- 1 \end{aligned} ∥u1​+u2​∥∥u1​−u2​∥​fl(fl(∥uˉ1​+uˉ2​)∥fl(∥uˉ1​−uˉ2​∥)​)−∥u1​+u2​∥∥u1​−u2​∥​​​=∥u1​+u2​∥∥u1​−u2​∥​∥uˉ1​+uˉ2​∥∥uˉ1​−uˉ2​∥​1+δ3​(1+δ1​)(1+δ2​)​−∥u1​+u2​∥∥u1​−u2​∥​​=1+δ3​(1+δ1​)(1+δ2​)​∥u1​−u2​∥∥u1​+u2​∥​∥uˉ1​+uˉ2​∥∥uˉ1​−uˉ2​∥​−1=1+δ3​(1+δ1​)(1+δ2​)​1−u1​⋅u1​1+u1​⋅u1​​​1+uˉ1​⋅uˉ1​1−uˉ1​⋅uˉ1​​​−1=1+δ3​(1+δ1​)(1+δ2​)​1−cosθ1+cosθ​​1+cosθˉ1−cosθˉ​​−1=1+δ3​(1+δ1​)(1+δ2​)​1−cosθ1+cosθ​​1+((1+δ5​)(1+δ6​)1​cosθ+Δ)1−((1+δ5​)(1+δ6​)1​cosθ+Δ)​​−1​

The relative error can approach infinity when θ→0\theta\to0θ→0, but is well bounded when θ→±π/2\theta\to\pm\pi/2θ→±π/2. Just as explained in the second method, the relative error will be more likely to be bounded at a slightly large value when θ→0\theta\to0θ→0.

In fact, the forth method has the exact same order of magnitude of relative error as the third method. Just notice that:

u1≔∥v2∥v1=v1∥v1∥∥v1∥∥v2∥=w1∥v1∥∥v2∥\mathbf{u}_1\coloneqq\Vert\mathbf{v}_2\Vert\mathbf{v_1}=\frac{\mathbf{v}_1}{\Vert\mathbf{v}_1\Vert}\Vert\mathbf{v}_1\Vert\Vert\mathbf{v}_2\Vert=\mathbf{w}_1\Vert\mathbf{v}_1\Vert\Vert\mathbf{v}_2\Vert u1​:=∥v2​∥v1​=∥v1​∥v1​​∥v1​∥∥v2​∥=w1​∥v1​∥∥v2​∥

where w1\mathbf{w}_1w1​ is a normalized vector. Substituting u1,u2,uˉ1,uˉ2\mathbf{u}_1, \mathbf{u}_2, \bar{\mathbf{u}}_1, \bar{\mathbf{u}}_2u1​,u2​,uˉ1​,uˉ2​ into the third method and we will get the same expression. Therefore, the relative error can approach infinity when θ→0\theta\to0θ→0.

Overall, the extrinsic and intrinsic relative error of each method can be summarized in the next table, where +++ means stable (bounded), −-− means unstable (unbounded) and ±\pm± means theoretically unbounded but practically bounded. The left symbol of ∗/∗*/*∗/∗ indicates the stability when the angle approaches 000, and the right symbol indicates when the angle approaches π/2\pi/2π/2. For example, −/+-/+−/+ means the method is unstable when angle approaches 000 but stable when angle is close to π/2\pi/2π/2.

Method 1 Method 2 Method 3 Method 4
Extrinsic −/+-/+−/+ +/++/++/+ +/++/++/+ +/++/++/+
Intrinsic +/−+/-+/− ±/−\pm/-±/− ±/+\pm/+±/+ ±/+\pm/+±/+

Experiments

First we evaluate the instrinsic relative error of each method (code is available at here). Results for θ→0\theta\to0θ→0 are shown in the next figure.

The first method is well bounded whereas the other three methods have a relatively large bounding value. This aligns with our conjecture that within the limited precision, the intrinsic relative error of the latter three methods comes with decent stability. As the angle gets much smaller, the relative error should be infinite.

The following figure shows results for θ→π/2\theta\to\pi/2θ→π/2.

As expected, the first and second method has unbouned value and the third and forth method is well bounded.

The following two figures respectively show the results for the overall relative errors for θ→0\theta\to0θ→0 and θ→π/2\theta\to\pi/2θ→π/2.

Only the first method has an unbounded relative error when θ→0\theta\to0θ→0 due to its infinite extrinsic relative error as θ→0\theta\to0θ→0.

Conclusion

Never use arccos⁡(⋅)\arccos(\cdot)arccos(⋅) to compute the angle between vectors! Use arctan⁡(⋅)\arctan(\cdot)arctan(⋅) to get a numerically stable result. Compared to intrinsic relative errors, the extrinsic relative error seems to make the greatest difference on the stability and even if the intrinsic relative error is unbounded, you can still practically obtain a numerically stable result with arctan⁡(⋅)\arctan(\cdot)arctan(⋅). If you do care about the intrinsic relative error, the third or forth method is all you need.

Appendix

I find it very interesting to ask this question: how many digits in the decimal form are required to fully express a 32-bit floating number smaller than 111?

For example, the floating number 2−2=0.252^{-2}=0.252−2=0.25 uses two decimal digits to express the floating number since it can be written as 2.5×10−12.5\times 10^{-1}2.5×10−1. The floating number 2−4=0.06252^{-4}=0.06252−4=0.0625 uses three decimal digits because it’s 6.25×10−26.25\times 10^{-2}6.25×10−2. More generally, any floating number fff can be represented in either the binary way or decimal way:

f=(1+∑i=1pbi⋅2−i)2−k⏟Binary representation=(1+∑i=1pbi⋅2−i)2ed1.d2d3⋯dm×10−n⏟Decimal representation,   bi∈{0,1},di∈{0,⋯ ,9}f=\underbrace{\left(1+\sum_{i=1}^pb_i\cdot 2^{-i}\right)2^{-k}}_{\text{Binary representation}}=\underbrace{\vphantom{\left(1+\sum_{i=1}^pb_i\cdot 2^{-i}\right)2^{e}} d_1.d_2d_3\cdots d_m\times 10^{-n}}_{\text{Decimal representation}}, ~~~b_i\in\{0,1\}, d_i\in\{0,\cdots,9\} f=Binary representation(1+i=1∑p​bi​⋅2−i)2−k​​=Decimal representation(1+i=1∑p​bi​⋅2−i)2ed1​.d2​d3​⋯dm​×10−n​​,   bi​∈{0,1},di​∈{0,⋯,9}

The binary representation is converted from the floating number’s internal bit-wise representation assuming precision p=23p=23p=23 under the 32-bit IEEE standard. When the exponential field is non-zero, an implied leading one is added, just as shown in the above binary representation. When the exponential field is zero, there is no leading one, so the binary representation becomes:

f=(∑i=1pbi⋅2−i)2−126f=\left(\sum_{i=1}^pb_i\cdot 2^{-i}\right)2^{-126} f=(i=1∑p​bi​⋅2−i)2−126

Okay, let’s go back to our question. To determine the digits for any floating number, we can first resolve a simpler case for floating numbers in the form of 2−k2^{-k}2−k. It’s very obvious that, the total number of digits of the plain decimal representation for 2−k2^{-k}2−k before normalization, is exactly k+1k+1k+1. For example, 2−1=0.52^{-1}=0.52−1=0.5 has two digits, 2−5=0.031252^{-5}=0.031252−5=0.03125 has six digits, both including the leading zeros. Then, if we use this number to subtract the number of zeros, we will get the answer we need.

How many leading zeros are there in the decimal form of 2−k2^{-k}2−k? The question is equivalent to finding the smallest integer nnn such that 10n⋅2−k≥110^n\cdot 2^{-k}\ge 110n⋅2−k≥1. We can transform this inequality:

     10n⋅2−k≥1⇒10n≥2k⇒nln⁡10≥kln⁡2⇒n=⌈kln⁡2ln⁡10⌉\begin{aligned} &~~~~~10^n\cdot 2^{-k}\ge 1\\ &\Rightarrow 10^n\ge 2^k\\ &\Rightarrow n\ln 10\ge k\ln 2\\ &\Rightarrow n=\left\lceil\frac{k\ln2}{\ln10}\right\rceil \end{aligned} ​     10n⋅2−k≥1⇒10n≥2k⇒nln10≥kln2⇒n=⌈ln10kln2​⌉​

Hence, the number of decial digits needed to precisely represent 2−k2^{-k}2−k is k+1−⌈kln⁡2ln⁡10⌉k+1-\left\lceil\frac{k\ln2}{\ln10}\right\rceilk+1−⌈ln10kln2​⌉. We can then fully express fff in the decimal form using this result:

f=d1.d2d2⋯dk+1−n×10−n, n=⌈kln⁡2ln⁡10⌉ is the number of leading zerosf=d_1.d_2d_2\cdots d_{k+1-n}\times 10^{-n},~ n=\left\lceil\frac{k\ln2}{\ln10}\right\rceil~\text{is the number of leading zeros} f=d1​.d2​d2​⋯dk+1−n​×10−n, n=⌈ln10kln2​⌉ is the number of leading zeros

We can test this result with some examples. When k=1k=1k=1, the result is 1+1−1=11+1-1=11+1−1=1, correct. When k=5k=5k=5, the result is 5+1−2=45+1-2=45+1−2=4, correct. When k=10k=10k=10, i.e., 2−10=0.00097656252^{-10}=0.00097656252−10=0.0009765625, the result is 10+1−4=710+1-4=710+1−4=7, correct.

With this formula, we know that the maximum number of digits to represent a 2−k2^{-k}2−k-like floating number in the decimal form is when k=149k=149k=149, and this number is 105105105. When k=149k=149k=149, the binary representation of that floating number has zero in the exponential field and one in the significant field, that is, 2−23×2−126=2−1492^{-23}\times 2^{-126}=2^{-149}2−23×2−126=2−149. Everything is perfect.

What about a general floating number? You may think: oh it’s easy, just take the maximum count of all 2−i2^{-i}2−i that contribute to the floating number and that’s the answer! Unfortunately, that’s not the case. Take 2−1+2−102^{-1}+2^{-10}2−1+2−10 as an example. The decimal representation is 0.50097656250.50097656250.5009765625, for which we must use up to 101010 digits to represent it, rather than 111 - the digit count for 2−12^{-1}2−1, nor 777 - the digit count for 2−102^{-10}2−10.

This happens because the number of leading zeros for each 2−i2^{-i}2−i is different. When a 2−i2^{-i}2−i adds to 2−j2^{-j}2−j, the leading zeros can be filled, thus increasing the valid digits.

We can first decompose fff into a series of 2−i2^{-i}2−i addition:

f=(1+∑i=1pbi⋅2−i)2−k=2−k+∑i=1pbi⋅2−(i+k),  bi∈{0,1}f=\left(1+\sum_{i=1}^pb_i\cdot 2^{-i}\right)2^{-k}=2^{-k}+\sum_{i=1}^pb_i\cdot 2^{-(i+k)},~~b_i\in\{0,1\} f=(1+i=1∑p​bi​⋅2−i)2−k=2−k+i=1∑p​bi​⋅2−(i+k),  bi​∈{0,1}

Then it’s equivalent to a series of addition of:

f(2−k)=d1.d2d2⋯dk+1−nk×10−nkf(2−(k+1))=d1.d2d2⋯dk+2−nk+1×10−nk+1f(2−(k+2))=d1.d2d2⋯dk+3−nk+2×10−nk+2⋯f(2−(k+p))=d1.d2d2⋯dk+p+1−nk+p×10−nk+p\begin{aligned} f(2^{-k})&=d_1.d_2d_2\cdots d_{k+1-n_k}\times 10^{-n_k}\\ f(2^{-{(k+1)}})&=d_1.d_2d_2\cdots d_{k+2-n_{k+1}}\times 10^{-n_{k+1}}\\ f(2^{-{(k+2)}})&=d_1.d_2d_2\cdots d_{k+3-n_{k+2}}\times 10^{-n_{k+2}}\\ &\cdots\\ f(2^{-{(k+p)}})&=d_1.d_2d_2\cdots d_{k+p+1-n_{k+p}}\times 10^{-n_{k+p}} \end{aligned} f(2−k)f(2−(k+1))f(2−(k+2))f(2−(k+p))​=d1​.d2​d2​⋯dk+1−nk​​×10−nk​=d1​.d2​d2​⋯dk+2−nk+1​​×10−nk+1​=d1​.d2​d2​⋯dk+3−nk+2​​×10−nk+2​⋯=d1​.d2​d2​⋯dk+p+1−nk+p​​×10−nk+p​​

Because nk=⌈kln⁡2ln⁡10⌉n_k=\left\lceil\frac{k\ln2}{\ln10}\right\rceilnk​=⌈ln10kln2​⌉ is a non-decreasing function, we can rearrange these floating numbers as:

f(2−k)=d1.d2d2⋯dk+1−nk×10−nkf(2−(k+1))=d1.d2d2⋯dk+2−nk+1×10−(nk+1−nk)×10−nkf(2−(k+2))=d1.d2d2⋯dk+3−nk+2×10−(nk+2−nk)×10−nk⋯f(2−(k+p))=d1.d2d2⋯dk+p+1−nk+p×10−(nk+p−nk)×10−nk\begin{aligned} f(2^{-k})&=d_1.d_2d_2\cdots d_{k+1-n_k}\times 10^{-n_k}\\ f(2^{-{(k+1)}})&=d_1.d_2d_2\cdots d_{k+2-n_{k+1}}\times 10^{-(n_{k+1}-n_k)}\times 10^{-n_k}\\ f(2^{-{(k+2)}})&=d_1.d_2d_2\cdots d_{k+3-n_{k+2}}\times 10^{-(n_{k+2}-n_k)}\times 10^{-n_k}\\ &\cdots\\ f(2^{-{(k+p)}})&=d_1.d_2d_2\cdots d_{k+p+1-n_{k+p}}\times 10^{-(n_{k+p}-n_k)}\times 10^{-n_k} \end{aligned} f(2−k)f(2−(k+1))f(2−(k+2))f(2−(k+p))​=d1​.d2​d2​⋯dk+1−nk​​×10−nk​=d1​.d2​d2​⋯dk+2−nk+1​​×10−(nk+1​−nk​)×10−nk​=d1​.d2​d2​⋯dk+3−nk+2​​×10−(nk+2​−nk​)×10−nk​⋯=d1​.d2​d2​⋯dk+p+1−nk+p​​×10−(nk+p​−nk​)×10−nk​​

The number of decimal numbers to represent the sum of these floating numbers depends only on f(2−(k+p))f(2^{-(k+p)})f(2−(k+p)) because k+1−nkk+1-n_kk+1−nk​ is also non-decreasing and 10−(nk+p−nk)10^{-(n_{k+p}-n_k)}10−(nk+p​−nk​) adds the most leading zeros. When f(2−(k+p))f(2^{-(k+p)})f(2−(k+p)) adds to f(2−k)f(2^{-k})f(2−k), the first digit, which is d1d_1d1​ of f(2−k)f(2^{-k})f(2−k) makes sures all digits after d1d_1d1​ is valid, that is, needed to represent the floating number. The final result is thus:

(nk+p−nk)+(k+p+1−nk+p)=k+p+1−nk(n_{k+p}-n_k)+(k+p+1-n_{k+p})=k+p+1-n_k (nk+p​−nk​)+(k+p+1−nk+p​)=k+p+1−nk​

But not all bib_ibi​s are 111, so in practice we first need to find the largest index 0≤p′≤230\le p'\le 230≤p′≤23 such that bp′=1b_{p'}=1bp′​=1, and we can compute the result by k+p′+1−nkk+p'+1-n_kk+p′+1−nk​.

What is maximum value of k+p′+1−nkk+p'+1-n_kk+p′+1−nk​ among all floating numbers? Note that p′p'p′ and kkk are independent, so we can take the largest kkk and the largest p′p'p′ and the result is 126+23+1−n126=112126+23+1-n_{126}=112126+23+1−n126​=112. This floating number has a zero exponential field and all-one significant field, i.e., the largest floating value smaller than 2−1262^{-126}2−126.
